import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session
source.a19d1710:
new_death_df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/effectiveness-of-covid19-vaccines-in-israel/New Death - vaccination.csv',
                          parse_dates=['Date'], dayfirst=True, index_col="Date")
new_cases_df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/effectiveness-of-covid19-vaccines-in-israel/New Cases - vaccination.csv',
                          parse_dates=['Date'], dayfirst=True, index_col="Date")
vaccinations_df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/effectiveness-of-covid19-vaccines-in-israel/Culmulativ pecentage of vaccines.csv',
                              parse_dates=['Date'], dayfirst=True, index_col="Date")
source.1414663c:
all_population_df = new_death_df[new_death_df['age group'] == 'All population']
all_population_df.columns
norm_cols = ['New Death  vaccinated per 100k',
             'New Death  expired Vaccination  per 100k',
             'New Death  Not vaccinated per 100k']
new_death_norm = all_population_df[norm_cols]
source.58c04f63:
# Get the rolling average for each group
new_death_norm['New Death  vaccinated per 100k'] = new_death_norm.rolling(window=7)['New Death  vaccinated per 100k'].mean()
new_death_norm['New Death  expired Vaccination  per 100k'] = new_death_norm.rolling(window=7)['New Death  expired Vaccination  per 100k'].mean()
new_death_norm['New Death  Not vaccinated per 100k'] = new_death_norm.rolling(window=7)['New Death  Not vaccinated per 100k'].mean()
source.e48b3e9b:
all_population_df = new_cases_df[new_cases_df['age group'] == 'All population']
all_population_df.columns
norm_cols = ['New cases vaccinated per 100k',
             'New cases expired Vaccination  per 100k',
             'New cases Not vaccinated per 100k']
new_cases_norm = all_population_df[norm_cols]
source.ebee07ab:
# Get the rolling average for each group
new_cases_norm['New cases vaccinated per 100k'] = new_cases_norm.rolling(window=7)['New cases vaccinated per 100k'].mean()
new_cases_norm['New cases expired Vaccination  per 100k'] = new_cases_norm.rolling(window=7)['New cases expired Vaccination  per 100k'].mean()
new_cases_norm['New cases Not vaccinated per 100k'] = new_cases_norm.rolling(window=7)['New cases Not vaccinated per 100k'].mean()
source.892221d0:
plt.figure(figsize=(16,8))
plt.title("New cases per 100k (rolling 7-day average)")
sns.lineplot(data=new_cases_norm)
source.9236082f:
vacc_pct_cols = ['Percentage of vaccinated first dose',
                 'Percentage of vaccinated second dose',
                 'Percentage of vaccinated third dose']
vacc_percent_df = vaccinations_df[vacc_pct_cols]

plt.figure(figsize=(16,8))
plt.title("Percentage of population vaccinated")
sns.lineplot(data=vacc_percent_df)
source.44859ceb: It looks like new cases began to increase a couple of weeks before the third vaccine dose became available. The new cases mostly effected the unvaccinated and not fully-vaccinated, but there were many breakthrough cases as well.

### Prepare data for plotting

The data is a littl bit spiky, so we'll show the 7-day rolling average.
